Dear Ms. Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency Restraint
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was placed in multiple unjust restraints.
Investigation Interviews:
Complaint Source/ MDHHS Worker 2 was interviewed via phone on
September 18, 2023. MDHHS Worker 2 reported she watched the video
footage of the restraint and reported the concerns to the facility. MDHHS
Worker 2 had no further information for the allegations.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on September
20, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Youth A shut down
verbally communicating within the interview once asked the forensic
interview questions. Youth A communicated during the interview via
writing in a notebook. She reported she feels safe at the facility because
the staff keeps her safe. Youth A reported Staff 3 was her favorite staff.
She reported she does not like Staff 1 because he will raise his voice at
her. Youth A reported Staff 1 is mad at her, and she has previously said
she was sorry to him. She reported she does not know why he is mad at
her. Youth A reported she does not remember being restrained or
running towards the road.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 20,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Chief Administrator
was present during the interview. Staff 1 reported he has been
working at the facility for almost two months. He stated he worked on
Sunday, September 10, 2023. When he arrived, he went to take Youth A
on an outing but the place he was taking her was closed. Staff 1
reported he offered to bring Youth A somewhere else, but she did not
want to go so they went back to her house. He stated he knew she was
bummed out about this, and he played a game of uno with her for about
30 minutes. Before playing the game, Youth A asked if Staff 1 could
push her chair in because she said it was too heavy. Staff 1 explained to
Youth A that she is strong enough to push her chair in, but he will do it
this one time. He stated after they played uno he went to heat his food
to eat dinner. Youth A got up for a little bit and then came back over to
2

play uno again. Staff 1 agreed to play with her after he was done eating.
Youth A then asked Staff 1 to push her chair in again and he told her no
and that she could do it herself. Staff 1 explained he was trying to get
Youth A to be more independent by encouraging her to do things on her
own. He reported this did not go over well with Youth A and she began
to yell. Staff 1 told Youth A if she continued to yell and be disrespectful,
he was not going to be playing uno with her. He stated Staff 2 tried to
deescalate the situation which is when Youth A then dysregulated and
started to hiss at staff. Staff 1 explained Youth A began to throw things
around the house and he called Program Manager for support. He
reported Program Manager came into the home to help but Youth A
continued to throw things around. Staff 1 reported he and Staff 2 did not
feel safe in the situation, and he asked Program Manager if they could
go into a restraint. Staff 1 reported Program Manager told him yes, he
could do a restraint. When asked what made him and Staff 2 feel
unsafe, he reported Youth A was throwing things and even though she
was not aiming at staff she was hitting staff with the items she was
throwing, and she was pushing Staff 1. He reported after the approval
he attempted to go into a restraint with Staff 2 and Youth A kept trying to
bite them. Staff 1 reported Program Manager told them to stop the
restraint because Youth A had her body bent over the couch. Staff 1
reported during all this time Program Manager was on the phone with
someone about another youth. He reported once Program Manager was
off the phone, he went into a restraint with Staff 2 with Youth A due to
Youth A’s assaultive behavior. Staff 1 reported he was directed by
Program Manager to go take a walk because Youth A was targeting
him, so he went to go sit in his car. He reported while in his car, Youth A
got out of the house and Program Manager was following her. While he
was in his car, Youth A began to bang on his car, and he was concerned
about the property damage being done to his car. Staff 1 reported he
was concerned Program Manager was not stopping her. He stated after
a short period of time, Youth A walked away, and Program Manager
continued to follow her. Staff 1 reported he got out of his car and went
back into the home. He stated he did not follow Youth A because
Program Manager had given him the direction previously to stay away
since she was targeting him, and he thought that was still the case. Staff
1 reported about 10-15 minutes later, Program Manager brought Youth
A back into the home and was upset with Staff 1 that he did not assist
when Youth A was outside. Staff 1 reported he was confused because
he had been told to walk away previously. He stated Program Manager
then left the home and Youth A was sitting in a chair near the front
entryway door. Youth A got up at one point and opened the door to the
walkway near the main entrance. Staff 1 reported he had some vision of
her through the window. He stated he got up about 30-45 seconds later
and noticed she had walked out the front door. Staff 1 reported he went
outside, and Youth A was heading towards the bridge. He stated he saw
Program Manager coming out of another house on campus after Youth
A. Staff 1 reported Youth A was running towards the main road and they
had given her the boundary of if she was to cross the sidewalk a
restraint would have to occur to stop her from running into the main
road. Youth A crossed that boundary and Staff 1, and Program Manager
3

went into a restraint with Youth A. Staff 1 reported this was a short hold
because Youth A dropped weight to the ground. Youth A then began to
throw dirt at Program Manager and refused to get back up. Staff 3 was
arriving back from an outing with Youth B and stopped for support. Staff
1 reported he drove the van back with Youth B so that Staff 3 could help
with Youth A. Staff 1 was asked if they were aware of the restraint policy
and when staff is allowed to go hands-on. Staff 1 reported staff can go
hands-on when there is an unsafe situation for a youth when they are
causing harm to themselves or others. He reported he felt all restraints
were appropriate when he was involved. Staff 1 reported more
frustration about the communication with Program Manager.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 25,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 2 reported she
started working at the facility in April 2023 and was working on
September 10, 2023. She reported when she arrived at work that day,
Youth A was on an outing with Staff 1. When Youth A came back from
the outing she was in positive spirits. Staff 2 reported Youth A can be
very dominant and a little bit controlling at times. She reported Youth A
was sitting next to Staff 1 at the table while Staff 1 was eating his dinner.
Staff 2 reported she heard Youth A ask Staff 1 to push her chair in and
Staff 1 told her no because he was eating his dinner. Youth A then got a
little bit louder and continued to say that he needed to push her chair in.
Staff 2 reported she told Youth A she could do move her own chair in
and Youth A responded by saying she wanted Staff 1 to push her chair
in. Youth A then began to hiss while Staff 1 got up to clean up his dinner
and Youth A followed him. Staff 2 reported she saw Youth A hitting,
chasing, and scratching Staff 1. She reported Staff 1 continued to try to
get away from Youth A but she followed him around. Staff 1 called
Program Manager over for support because Staff 1 and Staff 2 did not
know what to do with Youth A. Staff 2 reported Program Manager came
over quickly but answered a phone call while Youth A was throwing
everything around the milieu area. Staff 2 reported she was ready to go
into a restraint with Youth A due to the behaviors she was showing. She
reported she remembers asking Staff 1 to go into a restraint and then
asking Program Manager if they could restrain Youth A. She reported
she went into the first restraint with Staff 1 but Staff 1 did not have good
control, so they had to disengage. She reported Youth A continued to
target staff and be assaultive. Program Manager told Staff 1 to go take a
walk since Youth A continued to target him. Staff 2 reported she went
into a restraint with Program Manager due to Youth A’s behaviors. She
reported this restraint did not last long because Program Manager did
not have a good grip and had to release. Staff 2 reported Youth A ended
up scratching her and she was bleeding, so she walked to the staff
bathroom to clean herself up. She reported she received a phone call
from the delivery driver for her food to be picked up. Staff 2 reported she
went outside the home leaving Program Manager with Youth A. She
reported she saw Staff 1 outside and he stated that he was not going
back in the house because Youth A continued to attack him. She
reported she grabbed her food and tried to go in the front door, but
Youth A was trying to get out of the house at that point. Staff 2 reported
4

she went through the side door and then to the staff bathroom again.
She reported when she came out of the bathroom, Staff 1 was inside the
house and Program Manager was outside with Youth A. Staff 2 reported
they were outside for about 15 minutes and then Program Manager
brought Youth A back into the house. Program Manager left the house.
She reported Staff 1 was sitting at the table and Youth A was just
standing there. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 was scared to be left with Youth
A and did not know what to do. She stated she knew this because that is
what he told her. She reported the next she knew Staff 1 was running
out of the house after Youth A. Staff 2 reported she did not leave the
house because Youth C was doing an unsupervised visit with his mother
at the house and could not leave the house. She reported overall the
communication within this situation was not there. Staff 2 reported she
and Staff 1 were looking for guidance from Program Manager and that
was not happening. When asked when it is appropriate for staff to go
into a restraint with a youth, Staff 2 reported when a youth is showing
unsafe behaviors. When asked would you go into a restraint if they were
just throwing items in the home, Staff 2 responded no and stated she
went into the first restraint with Staff 1 because Youth A was hitting Staff
1 after being told to stop.
Program Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 20, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Chief
Administrator was present during the interview. Program Manager
reported he has been working at the facility for about ten months and
this was the first restraint he has ever completed. He stated on
September 10, 2023, he was the supervisor on campus for support, and
on that day he received a call from Staff 1 stating that he needed
support because Youth A was escalated. Program Manager reported he
was waiting on an important phone call from a medical doctor for
another youth on campus but still went into the home to assist Staff 1.
He reported when he arrived, Youth A was throwing things around the
home and he started to try to verbally de-escalate Youth A. Program
Manager reported during his verbal de-escalation, he received a phone
call from the medical doctor but continued to keep an eye on the
situation. He reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 attempted to restraint Youth A
but she pushed her body over the couch and Program Manager told
Staff 1 and Staff 2 to disengage from the restraint due to safety. After
being released Youth A continued to target Staff 1 and Program
Manager told Staff 1 to leave the area. Youth A continued to attempt to
attack staff and Program Manager called for a restraint hold with Staff 2.
Youth A then dropped her weight to the ground and the restraint was
released. Program Manager continued to attempt to verbally de-escalate
the situation and reminded Youth A she was not a cat as she was
hissing at everyone and not using her words. He stated during that time
Staff 2 left the home without telling him directly. Youth A went towards
the door down her bedroom hallway and Program Manager was trying to
call for support. He stated Youth A went out of the home and started to
attack Staff 1’s car while he was in there from the original time Program
Manager told him to leave the situation. Program Manager reported he
continued to try to verbally calm Youth A down while she was banging
5

on the car and she began to head towards the main road area. He
reported Youth A began to run by the bridge and the main commons
building where he continued to try to calm her down. Youth A did end up
scratching at Program Manager. He reported Staff 1 was not with him
during this time and he was alone with Youth A. Program Manager
reported he explained to Youth A what her barrier was from the road
and if she crossed that barrier she would be restrained for her safety
due to her potentially running into the middle of ongoing traffic. Program
Manager reported seeing Staff 3 heading to go out on an outing with
Youth B and called for Staff 3’s support. He reported he and Staff 3
ended up restraining Youth A due to crossing the safety barrier and
attempting to head into the road. Staff 3 was able to help calm Youth A
down and walk her towards the home. Program Manager reported he
brought Youth A back into the home where Staff 1 and Staff 2 were and
left the home after dropping her off. He reported he went to sit in his own
car which was in the parking lot. Program Manager reported after a short
period Youth A had exited the home for the second time and no staff
immediately followed her. He reported Youth A approached him and just
continued to hiss at him and took off running. Program Manager
reported his main focus was on Youth A and when they got to the bridge
on campus Staff 1 was found to be behind them. Program Manager
reported he does not know when Staff 1 left the home. He reported he
gave Youth A and Staff 1 the boundary of if she crossed the sidewalk
near the road she would have to be restrained. Youth A began to
assault Program Manager after that and made her way to the sidewalk.
He reported a restraint was completed with him and Staff 1 for about 20
seconds because Youth A went to the ground. Youth A remained on the
ground throwing rocks, dirt, and grass at Program Manager for about 20
minutes. He reported he called the therapist on call and Chief
Administrator about the situation. Staff 3 was able to come to talk with
Youth A and walked her back to the house after about five minutes.
When asked about the restraint policy, Program Manager reported staff
are only to go hands-on when a youth is in immediate danger of harming
themselves or others. When asked if he felt all the restraints were in line
with that he reported within the first restraint with Staff 1 and Staff 2 that
he would have not gone hands-on. Program Manager reported during
that time Youth A was just throwing items around the home and swiping
at staff not physically assaulting anyone.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 25,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 3 reported she
was working on September 10, 2023, but not at the home Youth A
resides in. She stated she was taking Youth B on an outing when she
saw Youth A and Program Manager getting near the busy road on
campus. Staff 3 reported Program Manager flagged her down for
support as he was the only one around with Youth A. She reported she
took the keys out of the car and assisted Program Manager while Youth
B stood on the side. Staff 3 reported Youth A was given the boundary to
not cross a certain spot because she would not be safe running into the
busy road. Youth A did cross the boundary and a restraint occurred with
Staff 3 and Program Manager on Youth A due to safety concerns. Staff
6

3 reported the restraint lasted a few seconds due to Youth A dropping
weight. Once Youth A dropped weight, Staff 3 was able to process with
Youth A and got her to walk back to the house. She reported she then
took Youth B to the outing but was called about 20 minutes later to
come back for support. When she got back to campus Youth A was near
the road but this time Staff 1 and Program Manager were there. She
reported she did not go into a restraint with Youth A but helped calm her
down. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 stayed with Youth B while she processed
with Youth A. Staff 3 was able to get Youth A into the car and back to
the house. Staff 3 reported she had no concerns with the way Program
Manager and Staff 1 were handling the situation when she arrived. She
reported the restraint she was in occurred due to the boundary being set
with Youth A and she crossed that boundary making it unsafe near the
road.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on October 4,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Youth B reported they
were in the car with Staff 3 when she got called from Program Manager
to help support with Youth A near the road. They reported they were on
an outing with Staff 3 at the time. Youth B reported when they arrived,
Staff 3 got out of the van and took the van keys. They stood by the van
and in an area where staff could see them. Youth B reported they did
not remember witnessing any restraint occur with staff and Youth A.
They reported they remember seeing Staff 3 was consoling Youth A
about the situation since they have a good relationship and Staff 1 came
over to Youth B to supervise them. Youth B reported they road back to
the house in the van with Staff 3 and Youth A. They remember Youth A
stating they do not like to be restrained by men and was able to process
the situation with Staff 3. Youth B reported they had no concerns over
the situation.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 20, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker
1. Supervisor reported he directly supervises Staff 1 and Staff 2. He
reported he has had no concerns with either of the staff’s performance.
Supervisor reported Youth A does not fully get along with Staff 1
because he follows through with the rules and does not let her get away
with things. He reported prior to this restraint Youth A had no issue with
Staff 1.
Conference call was held with MDHHS Worker 1 on October 17,
2023. MDHHS Worker 1 reported there are no findings to the
investigation.
Video Review:
Video footage of September 10, 2023, involving the use of restraint, was
reviewed on September 20, 2023, in collaboration with Chief
Administrator and MDHHS Worker 1. The video begins with Youth A
sitting in a chair next to Staff 1 in the main milieu area. Youth A is heard
asking Staff 1 to push in her chair and he encourages her she can do it.
7

She continues to vocalize that she cannot do it herself and needs him to
do it because they are too heavy. Staff 2 is in the kitchen area
encouraging Youth A that she can push in her chair and Youth A
continues to yell at staff that she cannot. Youth A begins to kick the
table and Staff 1 gets up from the table and heads to the living room
area. Youth A follows Staff 1 into the living room area and begins to
throw pillows and tip over chairs. Staff 2 comes into the living room area,
walks towards Youth A and continues to follow her as she throws items.
Both Staff 1 and Staff 2 are verbally encouraging Youth A to not throw
things. None of these items are thrown directly at staff. Youth A
continues to yell at staff and Staff 1 is seen calling Program Manager on
the phone due to Youth A's behaviors as overheard on the phone call.
Youth A then begins to hiss at staff and continues to knock things off all
the kitchen counters and Staff 1 and Staff 2 continue to try to verbally
de-escalate the situation. Within two minutes of the phone call Staff 1
made to Program Manager, he arrived at the home. Both Staff 1 and
Staff 2 tell Program Manager that they do not know what to do with
Youth A. Program Manager attempts to verbally de-escalate Youth A
but then answers a phone call. While on the phone, Program Manager
continues to try to verbally de-escalate Youth A while she is in the
kitchen asking what is wrong. Youth A just continues to kick things
around in the kitchen and hiss at staff. Youth A comes out of the kitchen,
walks up to Staff 1 and hisses in his face. Staff 1 attempts to walk away
from Youth A and she continues to keep her body right up next to Staff
1. Youth A pushes her chest onto Staff 1 and he continues to ask to give
space. Staff 1 is overheard asking about a restraint and Youth A takes
pushes Staff 1 with her right forearm. Youth A walks away and kicks
items on the floor. As Youth A was walking away, she turned back and
hissed at Staff 1 who was following her. He then grabbed her right arm
to go into a restraint when Youth A turned to hiss at Staff 2. Staff 2 then
grabbed Youth A’s left arm to go into a two-person restraint. During this
time Program Manager was on the phone and turned to watch the
restraint while on the phone. Youth A struggled with the restraint and it
lasted about 40 seconds before, Program Manager told Staff 1 and Staff
2 to release. After that release, Youth A begins to target both Staff 1 and
Staff 2 and continues to approach them and jab at them. Program
Manager puts the phone down and attempts to help Youth A by telling
her to stop and following her around the milieu. Staff 1 is overheard
asking what to do to Program Manager since Youth A continues to push
him. Program Manager then walks in between Youth A and Staff 1 and
engages in a two-person hold with Staff 2. Youth A drops her weight to
the floor and the staff disengages. Youth A attempted to pull at Staff 2’s
sleeve but she was able to get away. Youth A continues to approach
Staff 1 and Program Manager tells Staff 1 to go take a walk, which he
does. Youth A then turns her attention to Staff 2 and Staff 2 takes a
phone call and walks out of the home as well. Youth A attempts to follow
Staff 2 but Program Manager blocks her from going out the door at first
but then she exits the home getting out of camera view.
Documents Reviewed:
8

- Facility Restrictive Intervention Administrative Review Form
dated 09/13/2023- Administrator 1 completed video review of the
restraints that occurred on 09/10/2023. Administrator 1 reported
“he does not see imminent risk of bodily harm to self or others
prior to the first two restraint taking place. Youth A appeared to
not engage with staff while approaching Knapp Street, imminent
risk is present for the second two restraint.” The
recommendations requested was for Staff 1 and Staff 2 to meet
with the restraint training supervisors, conversations with Staff 1
and Staff 2 completed by supervisors about appropriate use of
personal phones and appropriateness of conversation around
youth and follow up with Program Manager on delivery of
feedback in the moment.
- MiSACWIS Restraint Reports: 163180206, 163170206,
162570208, and 162590207- The restraint reports were
consistent with the interview completed with Program Manager.
- Facility Restrictive Intervention Procedures last updated
08/2022- The procedure form notes, “Restrictive interventions
are only to be used in emergency situations and as a last resort
when an event/action is likely to result in imminent, serious
physical harm and/or loss of life and less restrictive measures
have proven ineffective. The use of restraint is not permitted for
youth engaging in property damage. Imminent risk of substantial
harm or loss of life must be imminent to engage in a restrictive
intervention. When considering the use of restrictive
interventions, the following criteria are required: a. Harm to
Self- The youth is physically attempting to substantially harm
themselves to the point where a staff person cannot safely
protect the youth or prevent harm without engaging in a
restrictive intervention. Or b. Harm to Others-
The youth is physically attempting to substantially harm others to
the point where a staff person cannot safely protect youth or
prevent harm to others without the use of a restrictive
intervention.”
- Staff 1 Human Resource File and Training Log- Staff 1 had no
disciplinary actions noted within his file prior to this incident. Staff
1 is up to date on all required trainings and is noted to have the
AEGIS Initial training dated 08/2/2023.
- Staff 2 Human Resource File and Training Log- Staff 2 had no
disciplinary actions noted within her file prior to this incident. Staff
2 is up to date on all required trainings and is noted to have the
AEGIS Initial training dated 04/05/2023 and the Aegis
Benevolent Holding Skills review training on 04/20/2023.
- Program Manager Human Resource File and Training Log-
Program Manager had no disciplinary actions noted within his file
prior to this incident. Program Manager is up to date on all
required trainings and is noted to have AEGIS Initial training
9

dated 11/23/2022 and the Aegis Benevolent Holding Skills
review trainings on 03/2/2023, 04/20/2023 and 06/22/2023.
Analysis Facility is found in violation of the emergency restraint rule as it pertains
to the first restraint Staff 1 and Staff 2 completed with Youth A. Per the
review of the video, Staff 1 initiated the restraint after Youth A had
pushed him and was walking away from him. At the time Staff 1
engaged in the restraint there was no immediate danger to Youth A or
Staff 1.
Technical Assistance
Throughout the course of the investigation, it was found that the lack of
communication within the team working in the home contributed to rule
violations found. This is seen within the situation as Staff 1 called
Program Manager for support and the Program Manager needed to take
a call for another crisis at the facility so there was no clear
communication about action steps to help support with Youth A’s
behaviors. There was a lack of communication of where staff were going
such as Staff 2 left Program Manager with Youth A in an escalated state
but never communicated that. There was also lack of communication
when Program Manager brought Youth A back to the home of what next
steps were. Technical Assistance was provided to the facility to work
with the team about clear communication when in an escalated
situation. It is also recommended for coaching to be provided with
Program Manager about clear and effective communication with team
members. This was Program Managers first time dealing with a restraint
since being employed at the facility and it would be beneficial to provide
some feedback on this situation as a whole and how to handle future
situations.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification;
Section debriefing; reporting
Description (1) The agency shall develop and implement written procedures
for health status screening, notifications, debriefing, and reporting
when a restraint, including an emergency restraint, or seclusion is
used.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was placed in multiple restraints and only 2 of 4 restraints
were reported.
Investigation Interviews:
Program Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 20, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Chief
Administrator was present during the interview. Program Manager
reported this was his first restraint write-up and did not know that each
report needed to be individually completed. He reported he takes full
responsibility for this not being completed timely. Program Manager
10

reported Youth A was restrained four separate times on September 20,
2023. He reported he was either present or participated in the restraints.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Chief
Administrator reported the policy is that staff need to complete a report
right after the restraint occurred and turn it into the supervisor. The
supervisor is the one to enter it in the MiSACWIS system. She reported
the reporting on these reports were not done timely. Chief Administrator
reported Program Manager completed the two restraints that occurred in
the road, and they were not entered into MiSACWIS timely. She
reported Program Manager forgot to send the two restraint reports that
occurred in the home until a few days later which made it so they were
not meeting their required timelines.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on September 20,
2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Chief Administrator
was present during the interview. Staff 1 reported he is aware that the
restraint report needs to be completed within the same day of the
restraint. He reported Program Manager was completing the restraint
reports.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Restrictive Intervention Procedures last updated
08/2022- The procedure form notes the following is required
for documentation when a youth has been restrained, “A
Restrictive Intervention Report must be completed as soon as
possible but no later than the end of the shift for any
restrictive intervention. The employee who initiated the
intervention is responsible for ensuring the Restrictive
Intervention report is completed and sent to the Report
Notification Group. If this is not possible, Campus Leadership
on during that shift is required to complete the report and
send it to the Report Notification Group. A MISACWIS
Incident Report must be entered by the Supervisor who is
supporting campus for the shift in which the restraint occurred
within 24 hours. The report will be approved within 48 hours
upon receiving it.”
- MiSACWIS Restraint Report 162590207- The date of the
